{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox academic |name = Susanna Elm |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|11|11}} |birth_place = [[Münster]], [[West Germany]] |nationality = German |occupation = Historian |discipline = [[Classics]] |alma_mater = [[Free University of Berlin]],
[[St Hilda's College, Oxford]] |workplaces = [[University of California, Berkeley]] }} '''Susanna K. Elm''' (born November 11, 1959) is a German historian and classicist. She is the Sidney H. Ehrman Professor of European History at the Department of History at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. Her research interests include the history of the [[History of the Roman Empire|later Roman Empire]], [[late Antiquity]] and [[early Christianity]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.classics.berkeley.edu/people/susanna-elm|title=Susanna Elm|last=|first=|date=|website=Berkeley Classics|publisher=|access-date=January 28, 2017}} She is [[Editing|Associate Editor]] of the journals ''[[Church History (journal)|Church History]]'' and ''Studies in Late Antiquity'' and is a member of the Editorial Board for ''[[Classical Antiquity (journal)|Classical Antiquity]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.classics.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/faculty/cv/ElmCV2012.pdf|title=Susanna Elm CV|last=|first=|date=|website=Berkeley Classics|publisher=|access-date=January 29, 2017}} == Career == Susanna K. Elm is the daughter of historian [[:de:Kaspar Elm|Kaspar Elm]]. She graduated from the [[Gymnasium Leopoldinum]] in [[Detmold]] in 1978. Afterwards, she studied Classical Philology and History at [[Freie Universität Berlin]]. In 1986, she graduated from [[St Hilda's College, Oxford]], where her doctoral thesis, ''The Organisation and Institutions of Female Asceticism in Fourth Century Cappadocia and Egypt'', was supervised by classical historian, John F. Matthews. She then worked as an analyst at [[J.P. Morgan & Co.|Morgan Guaranty Trust]] for a year before becoming assistant professor at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1989. In 1994, she became an associate professor and has held a professorship at Berkeley since 2002.{{Cite news|url=https://www.yumpu.com/en/document/view/7215310/curriculum-vitae-susanna-elm-department-of-history-dwinelle-|title=CURRICULUM VITAE Susanna Elm Department of History, Dwinelle ...|last=Yumpu.com|newspaper=yumpu.com|access-date=January 23, 2017}} In 2007, Elm was part of a University of California research team that won the [[Society for Classical Studies|American Philological Association (APA)]] Prize for Scholarly Outreach for creating middle-school course materials on the fall of the Roman Empire.{{Cite web|url=http://newsroom.ucr.edu/1760|title=UCR Newsroom: Antiquity Research Group Honored|website=newsroom.ucr.edu|language=en|access-date=January 23, 2017}} Her publications include ''Virgins of God: The Making of Asceticism in Late Antiquity'' (Clarendon, 1994/1996); ''Medical Challenges for the New Millennium: An Interdisciplinary Task'' (Kluver, 2001), co-edited with Stefan Willich; and ''Sons of Hellenism, Fathers of the Church (University of California, 2012).'' She has received a [[Rhodes Scholarship]] as well as fellowships from the [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]] (1995), the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]], and the [[Wissenschaftskolleg zu Berlin]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanacademy.de/home/person/susanna-elm|title=Susanna Elm {{!}} American Academy in Berlin|website=www.americanacademy.de|language=en|access-date=January 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202074454/http://www.americanacademy.de/home/person/susanna-elm|archive-date=February 2, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The book ''Virgins of God'' was a development of her doctoral thesis about female asceticism in early Christianity. Enthusiastic religious women sought virtue by engaging in [[spiritual marriage]] or becoming [[anchoress]]es. Elm recounted how the religious hierarchy restrained such practises, condemning some of them as heresy. Doug Lee, writing in ''The Classical Review'', praised the work as a "stimulating exposition which negotiates the complexities of the source material and subject matter with skill and assurance. ...one of the many strengths of the study is E's exploitation of little-known sources such as an anonymous treatise ''On Virginity'' (pp. 34–9 331–6) and [[Athanasius]]' ''Letter to the Virgins Who Went to Jerusalem'' (pp. 331–6)."{{citation |jstor=714136 |title=Review: Virgins of God |first=A. D. |last=Lee |journal= The Classical Review |volume=49 |number=2 |year=1999 |pages=451–453 |publisher=Cambridge University Press on behalf of The Classical Association}} Her book, ''Sons of Hellenism, Fathers of the Church'' was described by the [[Bryn Mawr Classical Review]] as 'a welcome and erudite study of Gregory of Nazianzus's intellectual engagement with the emperor Julian.'{{Cite journal|last=Storin|first=Bradley K.|date=January 23, 2017|title=Review of: Sons of Hellenism, Fathers of the Church: Emperor Julian, Gregory of Nazianzus, and the Vision of Rome. Transformation of the Classical Heritage, 49|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2012/2012-12-63.html|journal=Bryn Mawr Classical Review|issn=1055-7660}} In 2013, the APA awarded her the Charles J. Goodwin Award of Merit for the book.{{Cite web|url=http://www.classics.berkeley.edu/about/news/susanna-elm-receives-goodwin-award|title=Susanna Elm Receives Goodwin Award|last=|first=|date=December 9, 2013|website=|publisher=|access-date=January 28, 2017}} In a 2016 interview for ''Studies in Late Antiquity'', a journal which she edits, she described her writing and research as 'an integrated approach that combines written sources from authors that are Christian and non-Christian with documentary and material sources.'{{Cite news|url=http://www.ucpress.edu/blog/23147/editors-spotlight-meet-susanna-elm-associate-editor-of-studies-in-late-antiquity/|title=Editor’s Spotlight: Meet Susanna Elm, associate editor of Studies in Late Antiquity|language=en-US|access-date=January 23, 2017}} Elm is married to [[Tübingen]] jurist and European law expert [[:de:Martin Nettesheim|Martin Nettesheim]].{{cite web|url=https://www.jura.uni-tuebingen.de/professoren_und_dozenten/nettesheim/biographie|title=Biographie Prof. Dr. Martin Nettesheim|publisher=University of Tuebingen Law School|language=German|accessdate=February 14, 2017}} == Selected publications == * '''Virgins of God': The Making of Asceticism in Late Antiquity''. 1994. Oxford Classical Monographs. Oxford: Clarendon Press {{ISBN|9780198149200}} * ''Sons of Hellenism, Fathers of the Church: Emperor Julian, Gregory of Nazianzus, and the Vision of Rome''. 2012. Transformation of the Classical Heritage. Berkeley: University of California Press {{ISBN|9780520269309}} * (Ed. with Stefan N Willich) ''Quo Vadis Medical Healing: Past Concepts and New Approaches''. 2009. Springer {{ISBN|9781402089411}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elm, Susanna}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:German classical scholars]] [[Category:German academics]] [[Category:Scholars of Roman history]] [[Category:German historians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Classical studies]] [[Category:Women classical scholars]]

{{Merge from|Timeline of feminism|discuss=Talk:Timeline of feminism#Merge discussion |date=January 2018}} {{Globalize/US|date=January 2018}} This is a '''Timeline of second-wave feminism''', from its beginning in the mid-twentieth century, to the start of [[Third-wave feminism]] in the early 1990s.
{{toc limit|3}}
==Timeline==
[[File:EnovidBottle.png|thumb|upright=0.6|alt=Small pill bottle with red & white label.|first [[Enovid]]: the first [[combined oral contraceptive pill]].]]
=== 1960s ===
====1960====
* ''Enovid'' is approved for sale in the United States {{date|9 May 1960}} as a contraceptive pill by the [[Food and Drug Administration]]. (It had been approved three years earlier for menstrual symptoms.) Within three years, 2.3 million women are using "[[The Pill]]", as it became known, in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |title=A brief history of the birth control pill |last1=Nikolchev |first1=Alexandra |url=http://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/health/a-brief-history-of-the-birth-control-pill/480/ |date=7 May 2010 |website=PBS |publisher= |accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref> The arrival of the pill ushered in and coincided with the second wave of feminism.<ref>{{cite web |title=Beyond The Bedroom: What The Birth Control Pill Really Did For Women |author1=<!--staff writers, no byline--> |url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/05/12/sexual-revolution-planned-parenthood-unplanned-pregnancy-forbes-woman-health-birth-control-pill.html#71f744b82133 |date=12 May 2010 |website=Forbes |publisher=Integrated Whale Media Investments |accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref>
====1961====
* The report of the [American] [[Presidential Commission on the Status of Women]] found discrimination against women in every aspect of American life and outlined plans to achieve equality. Specific recommendations for women in the workplace included fair hiring practices, paid [[maternity leave]], and affordable [[childcare]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://learningtogive.org/papers/paper200.html |title=National Organization for Women (Informational Paper) |publisher=Learningtogive.org |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref><ref name="CWLU">{{cite web|url=https://www.cwluherstory.org/supplemental-writings/a-womens-liberation-timeline-1960-1977|title=A Women's Liberation Timeline 1960 - 1977|last=|first=|date=|website=CWLU Herstory Project|accessdate=26 July 2018|df=}} </ref>
====1962====
* The non-fiction book ''[[Sex and the Single Girl]]'' is released in the U.S. and sells two million copies in three weeks. Author [[Helen Gurley Brown]] encouraged women to become financially independent, and to become sexually active before marriage.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=[[Media, Culture & Society]] |title=Inventing the Cosmo Girl: Class Identity and Girl-Style American Dreams |last1=Ouellette |first1=Laurie |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/016344399021003004 |date=1 May 1999 |volume=21 |issue=3 |page=361 |publisher=[[SAGE Publications|SAGE]] |issn=0163-4437 |doi=10.1177/016344399021003004 |accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref>
====1963==== [[File:Betty Naomi Goldstein Friedan.jpg|thumb|[[Betty Friedan]], author of ''[[The Feminine Mystique]]'']] *Twenty years after it was first proposed, the [[Equal Pay Act of 1963|Equal Pay Act]] became law in the U.S., and it established equality of pay for men and women performing equal work. However, it did not originally cover executives, administrators, outside salespeople, or professionals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.eeoc.gov/epa/anniversary/epa-40.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114113957/http://archive.eeoc.gov/epa/anniversary/epa-40.html |archive-date=January 14, 2012 |title=The Equal Pay Act Turns 40 |website=The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission}}</ref> In 1972, Congress enacted the Educational Amendments of 1972, which (among other things) amended the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]] to expand the coverage of the Equal Pay Act to these employees, by excluding the Equal Pay Act from the professional workers exemption of the Fair Labor Standards Act.{{Citation needed|date=November 2012}} * [[Betty Friedan]]'s ''[[The Feminine Mystique]]'' was published, became a best-seller, and laid the groundwork for the second-wave feminist movement in the U.S.<ref name="CWLU"/><ref>Addison, Heather; Goodwin-Kelly, Mary Kate; Roth, Elaine (2009). Motherhood misconceived: representing the maternal in U.S. film. SUNY Press. p. 29</ref> * [[Alice S. Rossi]] presented "Equality Between the Sexes: An Immodest Proposal" at the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] conference.<ref name="CWLU"/><ref>{{cite web |author=National Organization for Women |url=http://www.now.org/history/founders.html |title=Honoring NOW's Founders and Pioneers |publisher=Now.org |accessdate=2012-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702020817/http://www.now.org/history/founders.html |archivedate=2011-07-02 |df= }}</ref> * [[Gloria Steinem]] went undercover as a [[Playboy bunny]] in a New York Playboy Club, and published the exposé "A Bunny's Tale" in Show magazine in two installments in May and June, 1963.<ref>{{cite |title=Gloria Steinem's 'a bunny's tale' – 50 years later |last1=Mills |first1=Niclaus |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/may/26/gloria-steinem-bunny-tale-still-relevant-today |website=The Guardian |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date=7 May 2013 |accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=I-"A Bunny's Tale" - Gloria Steinem - Show Magazine |last1=Steinem |first1=Gloria |magazine=Show Magazine |location= |publisher= |pages=90, 92, 94, 114 |url=http://dlib.nyu.edu/undercover/i-bunnys-tale-gloria-steinem-show-magazine |date=1 May 1963 |accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref>
====1964====
* [[Title VII]] of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] became law in the U.S., and it barred employment discrimination on account of sex, race, etc. by private employers, employment agencies, and unions. * The [U.S.] [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] was established; in its first five years, 50,000 complaints of gender discrimination were received.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iq-tests.eu/iq-test-Use-of-IQ-in-the-United-States-legal-system-910.html |title=IQ – Use of IQ in the United States legal system |publisher=Iq-tests.eu |date=2002-06-20 |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> * Haven House, the first "modern" [[women's shelter]] in the world, opened in [[California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jfsla.org/havenhouse/domestic_violence/shelter/prevention_education/C61#contentPrimary |title=jfsla.org |publisher=Jewish Family Service of Los Angeles |date=2012-05-29 |accessdate=2012-06-05}}{{Failed verification|date=June 2012}}</ref>
====1965==== [[File:Logo SNCC.svg|thumb|upright=0.7|Logo of [[Student Non-violent Coordinating Committee]].]]
* Casey Hayden and [[Mary King (political scientist)|Mary King]] published "Sex and Caste: A Kind of Memo",<ref name="Sex and Caste">{{cite web|url=http://www.carolsim.com/cwluherstory/CWLUArchive/memo.html|title=Sex and Caste: A Kind of Memo|website=The CWLU Herstory Website|accessdate=30 March 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331205231/http://www.carolsim.com/cwluherstory/CWLUArchive/memo.html|archivedate=31 March 2017|df=}}</ref> detailing women's inequality within the civil rights organization [[SNCC]].<ref name="Dear Sisters">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2uMwEGfAMSQC&pg=PA21|title=Dear Sisters: Dispatches From The Women's Liberation Movement|editor1-first=Rosalyn|editor1-last=Baxandall|editor2-first=Linda|editor2-last=Gordon|year=2000|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=0-465-01707-X}}</ref> * The U.S. Supreme Court case ''[[Griswold v. Connecticut]]'' struck down the only remaining state law banning the use of [[contraceptive]]s by married couples.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www4.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0381_0479_ZO.html |title=Griswold v. Connecticut |website=law.cornell.edu |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> * The case ''Weeks v. Southern Bell'' marked a major triumph in the fight against restrictive labor laws and company regulations on the hours and conditions of women's work in the U.S., opening many previously male-only jobs to women.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.library.gsu.edu/spcoll/pages/pages.asp?ldID=105&guideID=534&ID=3512 |title=Special Collections & Archives – University Library – Georgia State University |publisher=Library.gsu.edu |accessdate=2012-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226072658/http://www.library.gsu.edu/spcoll/pages/pages.asp?ldID=105&guideID=534&ID=3512 |archivedate=2012-02-26 |df= }}</ref> * The "Woman Question" was raised for the first time at a [[Students for a Democratic Society (1960 organization)|Students for a Democratic Society]] (SDS) conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marxists.org/subject/women/subject.htm#question |title=Women and Marxism: Marxists Internet Archive |publisher=Marxists.org |date=1940-08-20 |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> * [[EEOC]] commissioners were appointed to enforce the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|Civil Rights Act]]. Among them there was only one woman, [[Aileen Hernandez]], a future president of the [[National Organization for Women]].<ref>Wright, Susan (2005), The Civil Rights Act of 1964: Landmark Antidiscrimination Legislation, The Rosen Publishing Group</ref> * The term "sexism" was most likely coined November 18, 1965, in a report by [[Pauline M. Leet]] during the "Student-Faculty Forum" at [[Franklin and Marshall College]].<ref name="wordpress2007">{{cite web |url=http://finallyfeminism101.wordpress.com/2007/10/19/feminism-friday-the-origins-of-the-word-sexism/ |title=Feminism Friday: The origins of the word "sexism" |work=Finallyfeminism101.wordpress.com |date=October 19, 2007 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Shapiro-1985>{{cite journal |journal=American Speech |last=Shapiro |first=Fred R. |title=Historical Notes on the Vocabulary of the Women's Movement |jstor=454643 |publisher=[[Duke University Press]] |date=1985 |volume=60 |issue=1 |pages=3–16 |doi=10.2307/454643 |issn=0003-1283 |eissn=15272133 |quote=When you argue... that since fewer women write good poetry this justifies their total exclusion, you are taking a position analogous to that of the racist—I might call you in this case a "sexist"—who says that since so few Negroes have held positions of importance relative to the majority race, their exclusion from history books is a matter of good judgment rather than discrimination. Both the racist and the seixst are acting as if all that has happened had never happened, and both of them are making decisions and coming to conclusions about someone's value by referring to factors which are in both cases irrelevant.}} quoting {{cite conference |url= |title=Women and the Undergraduate |last1=Leet |first1=Pauline M. |author-link1= |date=18 November 1965 |publisher=Franklin and Marshall College |book-title= |pages= |location= |conference=Student-Faculty Forum |id= }}</ref>
====1966====
* Twenty-eight women, among them [[Betty Friedan]], founded the [[National Organization for Women]] (NOW) to function as a [[civil rights organization]] for women. Betty Friedan became its first [[List of Presidents of the National Organization for Women|president]]. The group is now one of the largest women's groups in the U.S. and pursues its goals through extensive legislative lobbying, litigation, and public demonstrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.now.org/organization/info.html |title=Information about NOW |publisher=Now.org |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> * Barbara Jordan was elected to the Texas Senate. She was the first African-American woman in the Texas legislature.<ref name=autogenerated1>TEXT_Allen, Ashley</ref> * Flight attendants filed Title VII complaints about being forced to quit when they married, got pregnant or reached age 35.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
====1967==== <!--[[File:Shulamith Firestone.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|[[Shulamith Firestone]], feminist and central figure in the early development of [[radical feminism]]; circa 1970.]]--> * Due to a new law, abortion in Britain was made legal under certain criteria and with medical supervision.<ref name="autogenerated1960">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/womanshour/timeline/1960.shtml |website=BBC Radio 4 |title=Woman's Hour – Women's History Timeline: 1960–1969 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * American feminist [[Valerie Solanas]] wrote and published ''[[SCUM Manifesto]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Winkiel |first=Laura |chapter=The 'Sweet Assassin' and the Performative Politics of SCUM Manifesto |editor-last=Smith |editor-first=Patricia Juliana |title=The Queer Sixties |location=N.Y. |publisher=Routledge |year=1999 |isbn=0-415-92169-4 |page=62}} (The author, PhD from English department, University of Notre Dame, was research fellow, Center for the Humanities, Wesleyan University).</ref><ref>Castro, Ginette, trans. Elizabeth Loverde-Bagwell, ''American Feminism: A Contemporary History'' (N.Y.: N.Y. Univ. ====1968====

====1969====
* The American [[Radical feminism|radical]] organization [[Redstockings]] organized.<ref>Willis, "Radical Feminism and Feminist Radicalism", p. 124.</ref> * Members of Redstockings disrupted a hearing on abortion laws of the New York Legislature when the panel of witnesses turned out to be 14 men and a nun. The group demanded repeal, not reform, of laws restricting abortion.<ref name="CWLU"/> * [[NARAL Pro-Choice America]], then called The National Association for the Repeal of Abortion Laws (NARAL), was founded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00781 |title=National Abortion Rights Action League. === 1970s === [[File:Cover_of_Kate_Millett%27s_Sexual_Politics_book_-_PD-simple.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|Cover of [[Kate Millett]]'s 1970 book ''[[Sexual Politics]]''.]]   [[File:RobinMorgan profile.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7| Photo of feminist [[Robin Morgan]], author of ''[[Sisterhood is Powerful]]''.]]   [[File:Bella Savitsky Abzug.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|Congresswoman [[Bella Abzug]] of New York in the 1970s.]]   [[File:Helen Reddy 1973 (cropped).JPG|thumb|upright=0.7|Publicity photo of [[Helen Reddy]] from The Carol Burnett Show.]]
====1970====

"... the book became almost a sacred text for the international women's liberation movement of the 1970s, notwithstanding sporadic criticism of aspects of its ideology from some feminists."</ref> * In ''[[Schultz v. Wheaton Glass Co.]]'', a U.S. Court of Appeals ruled jobs held by men and women must be "substantially equal" but not "identical" to fall under the protection of the Equal Pay Act, and that it is therefore illegal for employers to change the job titles of women workers in order to pay them less than men.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=14302099308500970559&hl=en&as_sdt=2&as_vis=1&oi=scholarr |title=Schultz v. |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> * The [[North American Indian Women's Association]] was founded.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jFY3CxmHk4cC&pg=PA319 |title=Chronology of Women's ====1971====
* Switzerland allowed women to vote in national elections. However, some cantons did not allow women to vote in local elections until 1994.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * Jane O'Reilly's article "The Housewife's Moment of Truth" was published in the first edition of ''Ms. Magazine'', which appeared as an insert to ''New York Magazine''. The O'Reilly article introduced the idea of "Click!," which O'Reilly described as the following: "The women in the group looked at her, looked at each other, and ... click! A moment of truth. The shock of recognition. Instant sisterhood... Those clicks are coming faster and faster. They were nearly audible last summer, which was a very angry summer for American women. Not redneck-angry from screaming because we are so frustrated and unfulfilled-angry, but clicking-things-into-place-angry, because we have suddenly and shockingly perceived the basic disorder in what has been believed to be the natural order of things." * Linda Nochlin's essay "[[Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?]]" was published in ''ARTnews''. This essay is largely considered a pioneering text of the [[Art history#Feminist Art History|feminist art history]] movement. * The first women's liberation march in London occurred.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * In the U.S. Supreme Court Case ''[[Reed v Reed]]'', for the first time since the Fourteenth Amendment went into effect in 1868, the Court struck down a state law on the ground that it discriminated against women in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of that amendment. The law in question—enacted in Idaho in 1864—required that when the father and mother of a deceased person both sought appointment as administrator of the estate, the man had to be preferred over the woman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.supremecourthistory.org/learning-center/womens-rights/breaking-new-ground/ |title=The Supreme Court Historical Society – Learning Center – Women's Rights |publisher=Supremecourthistory.org |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014022928/http://www.supremecourthistory.org/learning-center/womens-rights/breaking-new-ground/ |archivedate=2012-10-14 |df= }}</ref> * The [[Westbeth Playwrights Feminist Collective]] was founded in New York. It was one of the first feminist theater groups formed to write and produce plays about women's issues and to provide work experience in theatrical professions which had been dominated by men.<ref>Rea, Charlotte, Women's Theatre Groups in The Drama Review, vol. 16, no 2, June 1972, pg 87.</ref><ref>Lowell, Sondra, "New Feminist Theater," Ms. Magazine, Aug. 1972. p. 17-21.</ref><ref>Johnston, Laurie, "Sexism in Theater Can Be a Boon: At the Drama Desk Luncheon," Theater Section, ''New York Times'', February 8, 1973.</ref> * The song "[[I Am Woman]]" was published. It was a popular song performed by Australian singer [[Helen Reddy]], which became an enduring anthem for the women's liberation movement.<ref name="Arrow2007">{{cite journal |last=Arrow |first=Michelle |year=2007 |title='It Has Become My Personal Anthem': 'I Am Woman', Popular Culture and 1970s Feminism |journal=Australian Feminist Studies |volume=22 |issue=53 |pages=213–230 |doi=10.1080/08164640701361774}}</ref> * [[Women's Equality Day]] resolution was passed in 1971 designating August 26 of each year as Women's Equality Day<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.public.navy.mil/BUPERS-NPC/ORGANIZATION/BUPERS/WOMENSPOLICY/Pages/WomensEqualityDay.aspx |title=Women's Equality Day |publisher=Public.navy.mil |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110172114/http://www.public.navy.mil/bupers-npc/organization/bupers/WomensPolicy/Pages/WomensEqualityDay.aspx |archivedate=2012-11-10 |df= }}</ref><!-- overcite? <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nwhp.org/resourcecenter/equalityday.php |title=National Women's History Project |publisher=Nwhp.org |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> -->
====1972==== [[File:Ms._magazine_Cover_-_Spring_1972.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|Cover of Preview issue of ''[[Ms. magazine]]''.]]
* Britain's first feminist magazine, ''[[Spare Rib]]'', was launched by [[Marsha Rowe]] and [[Rosie Boycott]]. * Egyptian feminist [[Nawal El-Saadawi]] published her book ''[[Women and Sex]]''.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * American feminists [[Gloria Steinem]] and [[Letty Cottin Pogrebin]] co-founded [[Ms. (magazine)|''Ms. magazine'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msmagazine.com/about.asp |title=Ms magazine website |work=About Ms.|accessdate=August 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Steinem|first=Gloria|title=Who is Gloria?|url=http://www.gloriasteinem.com/who-is-gloria/|work=Gloria Steinem Official Website|accessdate=August 15, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221110011/http://www.gloriasteinem.com/who-is-gloria|archivedate=February 21, 2014|df=}}</ref> * The National Action Committee (NAC) was established to spur action by the Canadian government to implement recommendations made by the Royal Commission on the Status of Women (1970). Funded in part by the federal government and founded as a wide coalition of women's groups, NAC was seen as the voice of Canadian women. * The [[Equal Rights Amendment]] was sent to the U.S. states for ratification. The amendment reads: "Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex".<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/era.htm |title=History |publisher=Equalrightsamendment.org |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721112813/http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/era.htm |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Gloria Steinem at news conference, Women's Action Alliance, January 12, 1972.jpg|right|thumb|Feminist Movement leader [[Gloria Steinem]].]] * In ''[[Eisenstadt v. Baird]]'' the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that unmarried couples have a right to use contraception.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oyez.org/cases/1970-1979/1971/1971_70_17 |title=Eisenstadt v. Baird | The Oyez Project at IIT Chicago-Kent College of Law |publisher=Oyez.org |date=1972-03-22 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * The International Feminist Collective was founded in 1972 in Italy by [[Selma James]], [[Brigitte Galtier]], [[Mariarosa Dalla Costa]], and [[Silvia Federici]], to promote political debate and action around the issue of housework; the [[International Wages for Housework Campaign]], which grew out of the Collective, was a feminist global social movement founded in 1972 in [[Padua]], Italy. The Campaign was formed to raise awareness of how [[Homemaking|housework]] and [[childcare]] are the base of all industrial work and to stake the claim that these unavoidable tasks should be compensated as paid wage labor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.generation-online.org/p/fpdallacosta1.htm|title=The door to the garden|last=www.generation-online.org|first=Mariarosa Dalla Costa + EE + AB|website=www.generation-online.org|access-date=2016-12-06}}</ref><ref name="nplusonemag.com">[http://nplusonemag.com/more-smiles-more-money "More Smiles, More Money." N+1 Magazine. August 2013]</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=James|first=Selma|title=Is Transformation Possible? They Say We Can't. We Must.|jstor=20838923|journal=Off Our Backs|publisher=Off Our Backs. Inc|page=42}}</ref> The demands for the Wages for Housework formally called for economic compensation for domestic work but also used these demands to call attention to the affective labors of women, the reliance of capitalist economies on exploitative labor practices against women, and [[leisure]] inequality.<ref name="nplusonemag.com"/> * [[Title IX]] of the [[Education Amendments of 1972]], became law. It is a comprehensive federal law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in any federally funded education program or activity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/crt/about/cor/coord/titleix.php |title=Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 |publisher=Justice.gov |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> The Educational Amendments of 1972 also amended the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]] to expand the coverage of the Equal Pay Act to executives, administrators, outside salespeople and professionals, by excluding the Equal Pay Act from the professional workers exemption of the Fair Labor Standards Act.{{Citation needed|date=November 2012}} * The [American] [[National Women's Political Caucus]] was founded.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nwpc.org/history |title=History | National Women's Political Caucus |publisher=Nwpc.org |date=2012-09-02 |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029053715/http://www.nwpc.org/history |archivedate=2013-10-29 |df= }}</ref> * Gloria Steinem delivered her ''[[Address to the Women of America]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/speeches/gloria-steinem-addresses-the-nwpc#gloria-steinem-addresses-the-nwpc |title=Gloria Steinem Addresses the Women of America – History.com Audio |publisher=History.com |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * [[New York Radical Feminists]] held a series of speakouts and a conference on rape and women's treatment by the criminal justice system.<ref name="CWLU"/> * The Feminist Women's Health Center was founded in [[Los Angeles]] by [[Carol Downer]] and [[Lorraine Rothman]].<ref name="CWLU"/> * In [[San Francisco, California]], [[Margo St. James]] organized [[COYOTE|Call Off Your Old Tired Ethics]] (COYOTE) to improve the working conditions of prostitutes.<ref name="CWLU"/>
====1973====
* Women are allowed on the floor of the [[London Stock Exchange]] for the first time.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * American tennis player [[Billie Jean King]] defeated [[Bobby Riggs]] in the "Battle of the Sexes" tennis match in 1973. This match is remembered for its effect on society and its contribution to the women's movement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wtt.com/page.aspx?article_id=1252 |title=Billie Jean King, Mylan WTT co-founder |publisher=WTT |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015151834/http://www.wtt.com/page.aspx?article_id=1252 |archivedate=2012-10-15 |df= }}</ref> [[File:STOP ERA.gif|thumb|Symbol used for signs and buttons by ERA opponents]] * The [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled in ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'' that laws prohibiting abortion are unconstitutional. States are constitutionally allowed to place regulations on abortion which fall short of prohibition after the first trimester.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0410_0113_ZS.html |title=Roe v. Wade |publisher=Law.cornell.edu |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * The U.S. Supreme Court held that sex-segregated help wanted ads are illegal in ''[[Pittsburgh Press Co. v. Pittsburgh Commission on Human Relations]]'', 413 U.S. 376.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wearewoman.us/p/us-womens-rights-history.html |title=We Are Woman: Women's History |publisher=Wearewoman.us |date=2012-08-18 |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114114721/http://www.wearewoman.us/p/us-womens-rights-history.html |archivedate=2012-11-14 |df= }}</ref> * AT&T agreed to end discrimination in women's salaries and to pay retroactive compensation to women employees.<ref name="CWLU"/> * The [American] National Black Feminist Organization was formed.<ref name="CWLU"/> * The term "[[sexual harassment]]" was used in 1973 in "Saturn's Rings", a report authored by Mary Rowe to the then President and Chancellor of MIT about various forms of gender issues.<ref>Rowe, Mary, "Saturn's Rings," a study of the minutiae of sexism which maintain discrimination and inhibit affirmative action results in corporations and non-profit institutions; published in Graduate and Professional Education of Women, American Association of University Women, 1974, pp. 1–9. "Saturn's Rings II" is a 1975 updating of the original, with racist and sexist incidents from 1974 and 1975. Revised and republished as "The Minutiae of Discrimination: The Need for Support," in Forisha, Barbara and Barbara Goldman, ''Outsiders on the Inside, Women in Organizations'', Prentice-Hall, Inc., New Jersey, 1981, Ch. 11, pp. 155–171. {{ISBN|978-0-13-645382-6}}.</ref> Rowe has stated that she believes she was not the first to use the term, since sexual harassment was being discussed in women's groups in Massachusetts in the early 1970s, but that MIT may have been the first or one of the first large organizations to discuss the topic (in the MIT Academic Council), and to develop relevant policies and procedures. MIT at the time also recognized the injuries caused by racial harassment and the harassment of women of color which may be both racial and sexual.
====1974====

|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-07-09/opinion/smeal.betty.ford_1_betty-ford-equal-rights-amendment-era-vote?_s=PM:OPINION |title=Betty Ford, champion of women's rights – CNN web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/pubs/Biennial/125.html |title=Archived: Women's Educational Equity |publisher=.ed.gov |date=1999-09-30 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * [[Dell Williams]] founded the first |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref name="google1">{{cite ====1975====
* The [[Equal Pay Act 1970]] took effect in the UK.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * The [[Sex Discrimination Act 1975]] became law in the UK, making it illegal to discriminate against women in education, recruitment, and advertising.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * The [[Employment Protection Act 1975]] became law in the UK, introducing statutory maternity provision and making it illegal to fire a woman because she is pregnant.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> <!--[[File:National Organization for Women logo.png|thumb|upright=1.3|Logo of the U.S. [[National Organization for Women]].]]--> * In ''[[Taylor v. Louisiana]]'', the U.S. Supreme Court held that women could not be excluded from a ''venire'', or [[Jury duty|jury pool]], on the basis of having to register for jury duty, thus overturning ''[[Hoyt v. Florida]]'', the 1961 case that had allowed such a practice.<ref name="www-rohan.sdsu.edu">{{cite web |url=http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/dept/wsweb/timeline.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101001102332/http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/dept/wsweb/timeline.htm |archive-date=October 1, 2010 |title=Timeline |website=San Diego State University Women's Studies}}</ref> * The [[United Nations|U.N.]] sponsored the First International Conference on Women in [[Mexico City]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dz4wU64f_JYC&pg=PA225 |chapter=feminism |title=The Concise Encyclopedia of Sociology |first=Jo |last=Reger |editor1-first=George |editor1-last=Ritzer |editor2-first=J. Michael |editor2-last=Ryan |page=225 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |year=2011 |isbn=978-1-4051-8352-9}}</ref> * U.S. federal employees' salaries could be garnished for child support and alimony.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/cgi-bin/getcase.pl?court=us&vol=467&invol=822 |title=FindLaw | Cases and Codes |publisher=Caselaw.lp.findlaw.com |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * [[Tish Sommers]], chairwoman of NOW's Older Women Task Force, coined the phrase "displaced homemaker".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://feminist.org/research/chronicles/fc1975.html |title=The Feminist Chronicles, 1953–1993 – 1975 – Feminist Majority Foundation |publisher=Feminist.org |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * American feminist [[Susan Brownmiller]] published the landmark book ''[[Against Our Will]]'', about rape.<ref name="susanbrownmiller.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.susanbrownmiller.com/susanbrownmiller/html/against_our_will.html |title=Against Our Will |publisher=Susanbrownmiller.com |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> She later became one of ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'''s "Women of the Year" (see below).<ref name="susanbrownmiller.com"/><ref name="time.com">{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,947597,00.html | work=Time | title=WOMEN OF THE YEAR: Great Changes, New Chances, Tough Choices | date=January 5, 1976 | accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref> * NOW sponsored "Alice Doesn't" Day, asking women across the country to go on strike for one day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civilrights.uga.edu/cities/macon/now_strikes2.htm |title=Freedom On Film :: Civil Rights In Georgia |publisher=Civilrights.uga.edu |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * [[Joan Little]], who was raped by a guard while in [[jail]], was [[acquittal|acquitted]] of murdering her offender. The case established a precedent in America for killing as [[self-defense]] against rape.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://testaae.greenwood.com/doc_print.aspx?fileID=C8337&chapterID=C8337-1097&path=books/greenwood |title=The African American Experience |publisher=Testaae.greenwood.com |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120065522/http://testaae.greenwood.com/doc_print.aspx?fileID=C8337&chapterID=C8337-1097&path=books%2Fgreenwood |archivedate=2013-01-20 |df= }}</ref> * In [[New York City]], the first women's bank opened.<ref>{{cite news |first=Eric |last=Pace |date=October 24, 2003 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/24/business/judy-h-mello-is-dead-at-60-executive-of-women-s-bank.html |title=Judy H. Mello Is Dead at 60; Executive of Women's Bank |work=The New York Times |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * The [[United States armed forces]] opened its military academies to women.<ref name="www-rohan.sdsu.edu"/> * ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' declared: "[F]eminism has transcended the feminist movement. In 1975 the women's drive penetrated every layer of society, matured beyond ideology to a new status of general—and sometimes unconscious—acceptance." The [[Time Person of the Year]] award goes to American Women, celebrating the successes of the feminist movement.<ref name="time.com"/> * The [[Equal Opportunities Commission (United Kingdom)|Equal Opportunities Commission]] came into effect in the UK (besides Northern Ireland, where it came into effect in 1976) to oversee the Sex Discrimination and Equal Pay Acts.<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * The first "[[Take Back the Night (protest)|Take Back the Night]]" march was held.<ref name="themaneater.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.themaneater.com/stories/2010/9/22/students-take-back-night/|title=Students 'Take Back the Night' on Columbia streets|work=The Maneater|first=Jimmy|last=Hibsch|date=22 September 2010}}</ref> It was held in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] in October 1975, after the murder of a microbiologist, Susan Alexander Speeth, who was stabbed to death while walking home alone.<ref name="themaneater.com"/>

* The [[Equal Opportunities Commission (United Kingdom)|Equal Opportunities Commission]] came into effect in Northern Ireland to oversee the Sex Discrimination and Equal Pay Acts.<ref |publisher=Biography.com |date=1936-02-21 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref><ref name="avoiceonline.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.avoiceonline.org/cbcwomen/jordan.html |title=Women of the CBC > Barbara ====1977====
* The [[Canadian Human Rights Act]] was passed, prohibiting discrimination based on characteristics including sex and sexual orientation, and requiring "equal pay for work of equal value".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/h-6/ |title=Canadian Human Rights Act |publisher=Laws-lois.justice.gc.ca |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029010645/http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/h-6/ |archivedate=2012-10-29 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Frauentag 1914 Heraus mit dem Frauenwahlrecht.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|German poster for International Women's Day, March 8, 1914.]] * In the U.S., the first [[National Women's Conference]] in a century was held in [[Houston, Texas]]. ====1978====
*The ''[[Oregon v. Rideout]]'' jury decision, in which Rideout was acquitted of raping his wife, led many American states to allow prosecution for marital and cohabitation rape.<ref name="Woodworth-2016">{{cite web |last=Woodworth |first=Whitney |title=Rape and Marriage: A look back at the Rideout case |url=http://www.statesmanjournal.com/story/news/crime/2016/08/13/rape-and-marriage-look-back-rideout-case/88460204/ |date=13 August 2016 |website=Statesman Journal |accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref> * The [[Pregnancy Discrimination Act]] banned employment discrimination against pregnant women in the U.S., stating a woman cannot be fired or denied a job or a promotion because she is or may become pregnant, nor can she be forced to take a pregnancy leave if she is willing and able to work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eeoc.gov/laws/statutes/pregnancy.cfm |title=The Pregnancy Discrimination Act |publisher=Eeoc.gov |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * The Equal Rights Amendment's deadline arrived with the ERA still three states short of ratification; there was a successful bill to extend the ERA's deadline to 1982, but it was still not ratified by then.<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org"/>

====1979====
* [[Margaret Thatcher]] became the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/people/margaret_thatcher |title=BBC History – Margaret Thatcher |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * The feminist art piece ''[[The Dinner Party]]'', by American feminist artist [[Judy Chicago]], was first put on display at the [[San Francisco Museum of Modern Art]].<ref name="autogenerated1960"/> * ''[[Duren v. Missouri]]'', 439 U.S. 357 (1979), was a United States Supreme Court case in which the court ruled that the exemption on request of women from jury service under Missouri law, resulting in an average of less than 15% women on jury venires in the forum county, violated the "fair-cross-section" requirement of the Sixth Amendment as made applicable to the States by the Fourteenth.
=== 1980s ===
* In the U.S., the early 1980s were marked by the end of the second wave and the beginning of the [[feminist sex wars]]. Many historians view the second-wave feminist era in America as ending in the early 1980s with the intra-feminism disputes of the feminist sex wars over issues such as sexuality and pornography, which ushered in the era of [[third-wave feminism]] in the early 1990s.<ref name="end">As noted in: *{{cite book |author1=Duggan, Lisa |author2=Hunter, Nan D. |title=Sex wars: sexual dissent and political culture |year=1995 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |isbn=0-415-91036-6 |pages=}} *{{cite book |author=Hansen, Karen Tranberg |author2=Philipson, Ilene J. |title=Women, class, and the feminist imagination: a socialist-feminist reader |year=1990 |publisher=Temple University Press |location=Philadelphia |isbn=0-87722-630-X |pages=}} *{{cite book |author=Gerhard, Jane F. |title=Desiring revolution: second-wave feminism and the rewriting of American sexual thought, 1920 to 1982 |year=2001 |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |isbn=0-231-11204-1}} *{{cite book |author=Leidholdt, Dorchen |authorlink=Dorchen Leidholdt |author2=Raymond, Janice G |title=The Sexual liberals and the attack on feminism |year=1990 |publisher=Pergamon Press |location=New York|isbn=0-08-037457-3}} *{{cite book |author=Vance, Carole S |title=Pleasure and Danger: Exploring Female Sexuality |publisher=Thorsons Publishers |isbn=0-04-440593-6}}</ref> * In the 1980s the second wave spread to [[Turkey]]<ref>Badran, Margot, ''Feminism in Islam: Secular and Religious Convergences'' (Oxford, Eng.: Oneworld, 2009 ({{ISBN|978-1-85168-556-1}})), p. 227 (author sr. fellow, Ctr. for Muslim Christian Understanding, Georgetown Univ., U.S., & fellow, Woodrow Wilson International Ctr. for Scholars, Washington, D.C.).</ref> and to [[Israel]].<ref>Freedman, Marcia, ''Theorizing Israeli Feminism, 1970–2000'', in Misra, Kalpana, & Melanie S. Rich, ''Jewish Feminism in Israel: Some Contemporary Perspectives'' (Hanover, N.H.: Univ. Press of New England (Brandeis Univ. Press) (Brandeis Ser. on Jewish Women), 1st ed. 2003 ({{ISBN|1-58465-325-6}})), pp. 9–10 (author taught philosophy, Haifa Univ., & women's studies, Oranim Teacher's Seminary, 2d-wave feminist leader, & cofounder Women's Party, editor Kalpana Misra assoc. prof. pol. sci., Univ. of Tulsa, & editor Melanie S. Rich psychologist & chair, Partnership 2000 Women's Forum).</ref> [[File:Yvette Roudy.jpg|thumb|upright=0.85|[[Yvette Roudy]], former French Minister of Women's Rights.]] * The [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] was enacted by the [[Canada Act]] of 1982, and it declares (among other things), "15. (1) Every individual is equal before and under the law and has the right to the equal protection and equal benefit of the law without discrimination and, in particular, without discrimination based on race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age or mental or physical disability. (2) Subsection (1) does not preclude any law, program or activity that has as its object the amelioration of conditions of disadvantaged individuals or groups including those that are disadvantaged because of race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age or mental or physical disability....28. Notwithstanding anything in this Charter, the rights and freedoms referred to in it are guaranteed equally to male and female persons."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efc.ca/pages/law/charter/charter.text.html |title=Canadian Charter Of Rights And Freedoms |publisher=Efc.ca |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * In 1983, the women's minister of France, [[Yvette Roudy]], passed a law obliging all companies with more than 50 employees to carry out a comparative salary survey between men and women.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jon Henley in Paris |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/may/11/gender.france |title=France tries again to give women equal pay | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2005-05-11|accessdate=2012-10-31 |location=London}}</ref> * The Japanese Equal Employment Opportunity Law of 1985, effective in April 1986, prohibits gender discrimination with respect to recruitment, hiring, promotion, training, and job assignment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/2523634?uid=3739256&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21101217225471|title=Equal Employment Opportunities in Japan: A View From The West|author=Linda N. Edwards|publisher=Jstor.org|accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * The [[Guerrilla Girls]] formed in the early 1980s as a response to sexism and racism in the art world. Known for their protest art and their usage of gorilla masks to remain anonymous, the group actively calls out issues within the contemporary art world.

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Translatio imperii''''' ([[Latin]] for "transfer of rule") is a [[Historiography|historiographical]] concept, originating in the [[Middle Ages]], in which history is viewed as a linear succession of transfers of an ''[[imperium]]'' that invests supreme power in a singular ruler, an "[[emperor]]" (or sometimes even several emperors, e.g., the [[Byzantine Empire|Eastern Roman Empire]] and the Western [[Holy Roman Empire]]). The concept is closely linked to ''[[translatio studii]]'' (the geographic movement of learning). Both terms are thought to have their origins in the second chapter of the [[Book of Daniel]] in the [[Hebrew Bible]] (verses 39–40).<ref>Carol Ann Newsom and Brennan W. Breed, ''Daniel: A Commentary'', Westminster John Knox Press, 2014, p. 89.</ref>
== Definition == [[Jacques Le Goff]]<ref name="Le Goff">Le Goff, Jacques. ''La civilisation de l'Occident médieval''. Paris. 1964; English translation (1988): ''Medieval Civilization'', {{ISBN|0-631-17566-0}} – "translatio imperii" is discussed in Part II, Chapter VI, section on "Time, eternity and history".</ref> describes the ''translatio imperii'' concept as "typical" for the Middle Ages for several reasons: * the idea of linearity of time and history was typical for the Middle Ages; * the ''translatio imperii'' idea typically also neglected simultaneous developments in other parts of the world (of no importance to medieval Europeans); * the ''translatio imperii'' idea didn't separate "divine" history from the history of "worldly power": medieval Europeans considered divine (supernatural) and material things as part of the same continuum, which was their reality. Also the causality of one reign necessarily leading to its successor was often detailed by the medieval chroniclers, and is seen as a typical medieval approach.
Each medieval author described the ''translatio imperii'' as a succession leaving the supreme power in the hands of the monarch ruling the region of the author's provenance: * [[Adso of Montier-en-Der]] (French area, 10th century): Roman Empire → [[Carolingian dynasty|Carolingian Franks]] → '''[[Saxons]]'''<ref name=latowsky>{{cite book|title=Emperor of the World: Charlemagne and the Construction of Imperial Authority, 800–1229|first=Anne A.|last=Latowsky|publisher=Cornell UP|year=2013|isbn=9780801451485|page=71}}</ref> * [[Otto of Freising]] (living in German region): [[Ancient Rome|Rome]] → [[Byzantium]] → [[Franks]] → [[Longobards]] → '''[[Germany|Germans]]''' (=[[Holy Roman Empire]]); * [[Chrétien de Troyes]] (living in medieval France): [[Ancient Greece|Greece]] → Rome → '''[[Medieval France|France]]'''<ref>De Troyes, Chrétien. ''[[Cligès]]''. Circa 1176.</ref> * [[Richard de Bury]] (England, 14th century): "Athens" (Greece) → Rome → "Paris" (France) → '''[[England]]'''
Later, continued and reinterpreted by modern and contemporary movements and authors (some known examples): * [[Fifth Monarchists]] (England, 17th century): [[Babylonian Empire|Caldeans (Babylonians)]] → [[Persian Empire|Persians]] → [[Macedonian Empire]] → Rome → '''England''' (and the '''[[British Empire]]''' later) * [[António Vieira]] (Portugal, 17th century): [[Assyrian Empire|Assyro]]-[[Babylonian Empire|Caldeans (Babylonians)]] → Persians → Greeks → Romans → '''[[Portuguese Empire]]''' * [[Fernando Pessoa]] (Portugal, 20th century): Greece → Rome → [[Christianity]] → [[Europe]] → '''[[Portugal]]'''
Medieval and Renaissance authors often linked this transfer of power by genealogically attaching a ruling family to an ancient Greek or Trojan hero; this schema was modeled on [[Virgil]]'s use of [[Aeneas]] (a [[Troy|Trojan]] hero) as progenitor of the city of [[Rome]] in his ''[[Aeneid]]''. Continuing with this tradition, the twelfth-century Anglo-Norman authors [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]] (in his ''[[Historia Regum Britanniae]]'') and [[Wace]] (in his ''[[Roman de Brut|Brut]]'') linked the founding of [[Iron Age Britain|Britain]] to the arrival of [[Brutus of Troy]], son of Aeneas.<ref>Bratu, Cristian. "Translatio, autorité et affirmation de soi chez Gaimar, Wace et Benoît de Sainte-Maure." The Medieval Chronicle 8 (2013): 135-164.</ref>
In a similar way, the French Renaissance author [[Jean Lemaire de Belges]] (in his ''Les Illustrations de Gaule et Singularités de Troie'') linked the founding of Celtic [[Gaul]] to the arrival of the Trojan [[Francus]] (i.e. [[Astyanax]]), the son of [[Hector]]; and of Celtic Germany to the arrival of Bavo, the cousin of [[Priam]]; in this way he established an illustrious genealogy for [[Pepin the Short|Pepin]] and [[Charlemagne]] (the legend of Francus would also serve as the basis for [[Ronsard]]'s epic poem, "La Franciade").
== From the Byzantine to the Holy Roman Empire == The cardinal point in the idea of the ''Translatio imperii'' is the link between the Byzantine to the Holy Roman Empire. *[[Constantine the Great|Emperor Constantine I]] established [[Constantinople]], a [[New Rome]], as a second capital of the [[Roman Empire]] in 330. *After the death of [[Theodosius I|Emperor Theodosius I]], the Roman Empire is permanently divided into the [[Western Roman Empire|Western]] and the [[Byzantine Empire|Eastern Roman Empire]] (Byzantine Empire). *With the demise of the Western Empire in 476, the Byzantine Empire remained as the sole Roman Empire. *Byzantine Emperor [[Constantine V]] married his son [[Leo IV the Khazar|Leo IV]] to [[Irene of Athens]] on 17 December 768, brought to [[Constantinople]] by the father on 1 November 768. On 14 January 771, Irene gave birth to a son, [[Constantine VI|Constantine]]. Following the deaths of Constantine V in 775 and Leo IV in 780, Irene became [[regent]] for their nine-year-old son, [[Constantine VI]]. *As early as 781, Irene began to seek a closer relationship with the Carolingian dynasty and the Papacy. She negotiated a marriage between her son Constantine and Rotrude, a daughter of Frankish king Charlemagne. Irene went as far as to send an official to instruct the Frankish princess in Greek; however, Irene herself broke off the engagement in 787, against her son's wishes. *As [[Constantine VI]] approached maturity, the relationship between mother/regent and son/emperor was increasingly strained. In 797 Irene deposed her son, who died soon afterwards. *Some western authorities considered the Byzantine throne, now occupied by a woman, to be vacant and recognized that Charlemagne, who controlled Italy and many of the cities of the Western Roman Empire, had a valid claim to the imperial name. [[Pope Leo III]], crowned Charlemagne as [[Holy Roman Emperor|Roman Emperor]] in 800, an act not recognized by the Byzantine Empire. *Irene is said to have endeavoured to negotiate a marriage between herself and Charlemagne, but according to [[Theophanes the Confessor]], who alone mentions it, the scheme was frustrated by [[Aetios (eunuch)|Aetios]], one of her favourites.<ref>See Garland, p. 89, who explains that Aetios was attempting to usurp power on behalf of his brother Leo.</ref> * In 802, Empress Irene was deposed by a conspiracy and replaced by [[Nikephoros I]]. She was exiled and died the following year. * ''[[Pax Nicephori]]'', a [[peace treaty]] in 803 between the [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Charlemagne]] and [[Byzantine Emperor]] [[Nikephoros I]], [[Basileus]] of the [[Eastern Roman Empire]]. * Recognition of [[Charlemagne]] as [[Emperor]] ([[Basileus]]) in 812 by Emperor [[Michael I Rangabe]] of the Byzantine Empire (crowned on 2 October 811 by the [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople|Patriarch of Constantinople]]), after he reopened negotiations with the [[Franks]]. In exchange for that recognition, [[Venice]] was returned to the Byzantine Empire. * On February 2, 962, [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto I]] was solemnly crowned [[Holy Roman Emperor]] by [[Pope John XII]]. Ten days later at a Roman synod, Pope John XII, at Otto's desire, founded the [[Archbishopric of Magdeburg]] and the [[Bishopric of Merseburg]], bestowed the [[pallium]] on the [[Archbishop of Salzburg]] and [[Archbishop of Trier]], and confirmed the appointment of [[Ratherius|Rather]] as [[Bishop of Verona]]. The next day, the emperor issued a decree, the famous ''[[Diploma Ottonianum]]'', in which he confirmed the Roman Church in its possessions, particularly those granted by the [[Donation of Pepin]].
